verses.text: David took counsel with the commanders of thousands and of hundreds, with every leader.
verses.comment: Accurately reflects the sense of David consulting his military and civil leaders.

verses.text: And David said to all the assembly of Israel, “If it seems good to you, and if it is from the Lord our God, let us send word to our brothers everywhere who are left in all the land of Israel, and to the priests and Levites who are with them in the cities with their pasturelands, that they may gather to us.”
verses.comment: Keeps the sense of the original Hebrew, using 'assembly' for 'congregation'.

verses.text: “And let us bring back the ark of our God to us, for we did not seek it during the days of Saul.”
verses.comment: The phrase 'did not seek it' is a direct rendering of the Hebrew.

verses.text: And all the assembly agreed to do so, for the thing seemed right in the eyes of all the people.
verses.comment: Rendered as 'the thing seemed right in the eyes of all the people' to match the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: So David assembled all Israel from the Shihor of Egypt to Lebo-hamath, to bring the ark of God from Kiriath-jearim.
verses.comment: Retains the place names in transliterated form.

verses.text: And David and all Israel went up to Baalah, that is, to Kiriath-jearim, which belonged to Judah, to bring up from there the ark of God, which is called by the Name of the Lord, who sits enthroned above the cherubim.
verses.comment: Rendered 'called by the Name of the Lord' as per Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: And they carried the ark of God on a new cart, from the house of Abinadab. And Uzza and Ahio were driving the cart.
verses.comment: Maintains the literal sense of Uzza and Ahio 'driving the cart'.

verses.text: And David and all Israel were celebrating before God with all their might, with songs and with lyres and harps and tambourines and cymbals and trumpets.
verses.comment: Maintains the original list of musical instruments.

verses.text: And when they came to the threshing floor of Chidon, Uzza put out his hand to hold the ark, for the oxen stumbled.
verses.comment: Follows the Masoretic Text reading 'Chidon' instead of 'Nachon' in Samuel.

verses.text: And the anger of the Lord burned against Uzza, and He struck him down because he put out his hand to the ark; and he died there before God.
verses.comment: Rendered 'burned against Uzza' as literal translation of Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: And David was angry because the Lord had broken out against Uzza, so he called that place Perez-uzza, to this day.
verses.comment: 'Perez-uzza' means 'outburst against Uzza', as a place-name explanation.

verses.text: And David was afraid of God that day, and he said, “How can I bring the ark of God to me?”
verses.comment: Retains the meaning of David fearing God after the incident.

verses.text: So David did not move the ark to himself into the city of David, but took it aside to the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.
verses.comment: 'Gittite' could mean someone from Gath or the Levite city of Gath-rimmon.

verses.text: And the ark of God remained with the family of Obed-edom in his house for three months. And the Lord blessed the household of Obed-edom and all that he had.
verses.comment: Ends the chapter with a summary as in the Masoretic text.
